Award.AwardTitle: Origin, Storm Track Dynamics and Convective Feedback of African Easterly Waves
Award.AbstractNarration:
African Easterly Waves (AEWs) are north-south undulations of the African Easterly jet with wavelengths of 2,000 to 2,500 kilometers that form as far east as Sudan and propagate westward across the Sahel. They are the principle form of large-scale weather variability over the Sahel in summer and play a key role in bringing monsoon rains to this drought-prone region. When AEWs continue their westward (or easterly) propagation over the Atlantic they can develop into hurricanes, and it is estimated that 85% of major Atlantic hurricanes (including hurricane Sandy) form from AEWs. However, existing theories for the origin and evolution of AEWs do not satisfactorily account for many of their observed characteristics.

This project investigates several aspects of AEWs, including their origin and evolution, the structure of the AEW stormtrack (the typical pathway along which AEWs develop and propagate), intermittency in AEW activity, and interactions between AEWs and moist convection. A key component of the research, developed in previous work by the Principal Investigator (PI), is the idea that AEWs are organized into wave packets in which the dispersion of energy can be tracked according to an empirically determined group velocity. The dynamics are somewhat equivalent to the "downstream development" observed in synoptic weather systems moving along the midlatitude stormtracks, except that in the case of AEWs the energy propagation can be upstream or downstream (as AEWs form along the African Easterly Jet, the upstream direction is eastward). Upstream energy propagation could have a number of significant consequences, including the possibility that energy from mature AEWs on the western end of the stormtrack could propagate to the region of AEW genesis on the eastern end of the stormtrack, thereby promoting the genesis of new AEWs. To some extent, the consequences of upstream and downstream propagation can be interpreted as the difference between convective and absolute instabilities of a unstable jet of limited zonal extent. In convective instability, wave packets growing on the instability of the jet have downstream energy propagation which moves the packet out of the unstable region. In absolute instability, the group velocity at the trailing end of the wave packet is upstream, so that some of the wave packet energy remains in the unstable region and promotes further growth. Thus, intermittency in AEW activity could be caused by a transition from absolute to convective instability, as in the latter case the energy does not propagate upstream into the AEW genesis region.

The primary tool for research in this project is the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model, a regional atmosphere model applied over Africa north of the equator and the adjacent portion of the Atlantic. Model simulations are performed using both the standard full-physics version of the model and an intermediate complexity version in which external thermal forcing terms are used to produce an idealized version of the African Easterly Jet and AEW stormtrack. In addition to simulations designed to examine the role of upstream and downstream energy dispersion, additional numerical experiments are planned to examine the dual structure often observed in the AEW stormtrack, in which southern and northern branches of the stormtrack are found in the free atmosphere (around 650mb) and in the boundary layer (925mb), respectively. Coupling of AEWs to convection is also studied, using the full-physics version of the model. Results of these simulations will be compared to field campaign data collected in the African Monsoon Multidisciplinary Analysis (AMMA) field campaign.

The work has broader impacts due to the links between AEWs and Atlantic hurricanes, including landfalling US hurricanes, and the monsoon rains of the Sahel. A better understanding of the fundamental dynamics of AEWs could be of value for forecasting both individual AEWs and also periods of enhanced or reduced AEW activity. In addition, the work will support and train two graduate students, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to examine the role of moist convection and dynamics underpinning African easterly waves (AEWs). These waves are important to study because they are the primary weather producing disturbances over North Africa and Atlantic. Also of note is that the majority of Atlantic hurricanes originate from AEWs. Thus, they have a significant societal impact within North Africa and the Americas.

Intellectual Merit


Rotational Stratiform Instability as a Conceptual Model for AEWs:

We developed a conceptual model for AEW destabilization that relies on the phasing of the response to latent heating in organized cloud complexes and the AEW trough. Supporting diagnostics for this model was based on cloud-resolving numerical simulations and examination of potential vorticity budgets and diabatic heating profiles. In our simulations, multiple cloud systems and their regions of high and expansive clouds formed within the trough region of the AEWs. Precipitation and latent heat release promoted regions of rotation that we interpret in terms of balanced dynamics. This showed how, in nature, precipitating moist convection can maintain or amplify AEWs. We also presented an argument that that contrary to the assertions in prior studies, the canonical diabatic Rossby wave model is likely not applicable to AEWs.

Wavepackets and Instability of easterly waves

The existence of AEWs has traditionally been accounted for by energy transfer from the background flow to the waves via hydrodynamic instability. The key feature of the background flow is the mid-tropospheric African easterly jet (AEJ). A few studies have suggested that the AEJ is too short to sustain the amplification of AEWs. We used simulations with a simple general circulation model and showed that AEWs occur in groups or wavepackets.  We showed that the packets remain nearly stationary within the jet. Importantly, because the waves were not swept out of the jet, their residence time over the region was extended. We claimed that in nature this will provide opportunity for them to amplify via feedback from additional sources of energy associated with rain-producing cloud systems and Saharan mineral dust. Thus, our results showed the importance of wavepacket behavior in understanding how AEWs are maintained in the real atmosphere.



Elevated Topography over North Africa and the formation of AEWs

In regions of North Africa, where AEWs develop and move westward, there are several prominent areas of elevated terrain. Numerous previous studies have implicated organized cloud systems (e.g., mesoscale convective complexes) that develop in regions downstream of these terrain features over North Africa in the formation of AEWs. We examined the effect of four such terrain features on AEW activity as simulated by a weather prediction model. We compared simulations with these terrain features removed with our control simulation with unmodified terrain. We performed 10 years of simulation for each terrain feature. We found that the Ethiopian Highlands had the greatest impact on the southern track AEWs while the Tibesti and Hoggar mountains impacted the northern track AEWs. In both cases, removing the terrain led to reduced downstream AEW activity. We diagnosed the physical mechanisms for sensitivity. For example, our results suggest that, while terrain features are not necessary for the generation of AEWs, their reduction was followed by diminished AEW activity via reduced feedback from latent heat generation from organized cloud systems. Our results further support the view that AEWs need moist convection for their maintenance.


Atlantic hurricanes and AEWs

We updated the statistics of the relationship between Atlantic tropical cyclones (TCs) and AEWs. We found that 61 percent of TCs originate directly and, an additional 11 percent indirectly, from AEWs.  Interestingly, the correlation between the seasonal average TC number and a measure of AEW activity was maximized in the lower troposphere, instead of the mid-troposphere where the canonical AEW peaks in strength. In most seasons, there is an oversupply of AEW activity. AEWs appear to be a controlling factor only in seasons when they are less active. This result has important implications for the prediction of seasonal hurricane activity in the Atlantic.



Broader Impacts

This project allowed the PI to engage in several collaborative, serendipitous and mentoring activities. The results of the project were shared with the wider scientific community via conference presentations and peer-reviewed journal publications. Examples:

Impact of recurving typhoons on extratropical predictability

This work stemmed from the application of tools developed for the primary project objective. It is known that recurving typhoons lead to forecast skill loss, but how widespread is the impact? To answer this, we used data from a weather forecast model. We found that, compared to the baseline skill loss due to the chaotic nature of the atmosphere, the effect of the typhoon peaked 4 days after recurvature and returned to baseline thereafter. This shed light on the window of predictability associated with these high impact events.


The PI mentored 2 doctoral, several undergraduate and 2 high school students, including those from underrepresented groups (minority and first time college).
